Agreed, I learned about Smalltalk whitout the benefit of SUnit.
Typing some fragments of code and executing them ("inspect it...", or "do
it...").
When starting with java, I tried to do it the same way (VisualAge offers
similar funcionality in the scrapbook).
Switching to forte, I had a test class with a main method, where I typed
some code to see what it did.
I believe that's a very common way to explore any programming language...
Now I put all that exploring code in testcases, so I can use them as
documentation later. 
Wouldn't want to start counting how often I "explored"
Class.isAssignableFrom(Class) - amongst others. Whenever I read the javadoc:


   "Determines if the class or interface represented by this Class object is
either the same as, 
    or is a superclass or
    superinterface of, the class or interface represented by 
    the specified Class parameter."

I start panicking. The method name does not help either
(Class.isSuperTypeOf(Class) would be clearer).

    public void testIsAssignableFrom(){
        assertTrue(Number.class.isAssignableFrom(Integer.class));
    }

is much clearer to me, poor programmer.
Meaning: "an instance of class Integer can be assigned to a variable of type
Number".
or "Number is a super class of Integer".

BTW, JB, is this what you call learning tests ?
